item.title: IPCC Report sounds alarming but offers hope
item.description: The lastest IPCC report is a stark reminder that time is running out to change course. But it also confirms that tools are available to limit global warming and effects of climate change.
item.keywords: DWVC,IPCC Report, Climate Change, Global Warming, Environment
item.media:title: IPCC Report sounds alarming but offers hope
item.media:keywords: DWVC,IPCC Report, Climate Change, Global Warming, Environment

item.title: Syria's school system devastated by quake
item.description: 60 out of 86 schools in the region hit by the February 6 earthquake sustained damage. With no concrete repair plans by the international community, repair efforts are severely limited - and the situation is disastrous for Syria's schoolchildren.
item.keywords: DWVC,Syria, school, education, earthquake, UNICEF, student
item.media:title: Syria's school system devastated by quake
item.media:keywords: DWVC,Syria, school, education, earthquake, UNICEF, student

item.title: Clean energy: the global race for raw materials
item.description: Europe's green energy transition is dependent on China's supply of the raw materials needed to power wind turbines, electric cars and other green technologies. @DW
item.keywords: DWVC,Clean energy, EU, China, raw materials, Lithium, green technology, electric cars, environment
item.media:title: Clean energy: the global race for raw materials
item.media:keywords: DWVC,Clean energy, EU, China, raw materials, Lithium, green technology, electric cars, environment

item.title: Mice with two biological dads
item.description: Japanese scientists say they have created mice with two biological fathers, by turning male mouse skin cells into female egg cells. This technology is still very new. But in the future, it could lead to whole new possibilities in reproductive medicine.
item.keywords: DWVC,Science, Japan, mice, technology, reproductive medicine
item.media:title: Mice with two biological dads
item.media:keywords: DWVC,Science, Japan, mice, technology, reproductive medicine

item.title: Are you scared of getting Alzheimer's? AI might be able to help!
item.description: Alzheimer's is still untreatable, but early detection can slow it down. US researchers used AI to discover a predisposition for the disease during routine checks.
item.keywords: DWVC,Alzheimer's disease, Artificial Intelligence, Technology, Science, US research, early detection
item.media:title: Are you scared of getting Alzheimer's? AI might be able to help!
item.media:keywords: DWVC,Alzheimer's disease, Artificial Intelligence, Technology, Science, US research, early detection

item.title: Deadly earthquake jolts Ecuador and Peru
item.description: A powerful earthquake hit southern Ecuador and northern Peru on March 18, killing at least 15 people and leaving hundreds injured. There were destroyed buildings, crushed vehicles and debris seen in the streets of several cities.
item.keywords: DWVC,earthquake, Ecuador, Peru, natural disaster, death, injury, destroyed buildings, debris
item.media:title: Deadly earthquake jolts Ecuador and Peru
item.media:keywords: DWVC,earthquake, Ecuador, Peru, natural disaster, death, injury, destroyed buildings, debris

item.title: Solar tiles could help Germany's transition to solar power
item.description: A startup from Prenzlau, Germany, is seeking to disrupt the solar panels market with new tiles that can be installed on roofs to generate power.
item.keywords: DWVC,startup, Germany, solar panels, tiles, roof, power generation, renewable energy, innovation, disruption, climate change, business, green energy
item.media:title: Solar tiles could help Germany's transition to solar power
item.media:keywords: DWVC,startup, Germany, solar panels, tiles, roof, power generation, renewable energy, innovation, disruption, climate change, business, green energy

item.title: Holiday rentals push people to the suburbs
item.description: Tenants in Buenos Aires are calling for the regulation of tourist rentals, which affect 20,000 homes and make it more expensive for them to rent them out. Landlords who rent to travelers are opposed and argue that they are making a living. The Argentine capital does not regulate such properties, as do Berlin, Paris, Barcelona, and New York.
item.keywords: DWVC,tenants, Buenos Aires, regulation, tourist rentals, homes, rent, landlords, travelers, Argentina, living
item.media:title: Holiday rentals push people to the suburbs
item.media:keywords: DWVC,tenants, Buenos Aires, regulation, tourist rentals, homes, rent, landlords, travelers, Argentina, living

item.title: Three things you need to know about the global banking system
item.description: Is the global banking system about to collapse? Here are three things you need to know.
item.keywords: DWVC,Banks, Banking System, collapse, Silicon Valley Bank, Credit Suisse, economy, business
item.media:title: Three things you need to know about the global banking system

item.title: Why are researchers so excited about Mars?
item.description: Mars is more than 56 million kilometers from Earth. It is only 384,400 km to the moon. Why is research still more interested in Mars? @DW
item.media:title: Why are researchers so excited about Mars?
